faculty_name: Faculty of Computational Mathematics and Cybernetics
project_title: Particle motion in a temperature gradient

sections.heading: Main actions
items: - Press "Demonstration" to open the interactive scene and tweak parameters in real time.
- "Theory" and "Authors" show reference sections, while "Exit" closes the program.
- The RU/EN pill in the header switches the interface language; you can tap it anytime.

sections.heading: Slider controls
items: - "Number of molecules" sets how many particles live inside the box. Click "Apply" afterward to rebuild the system.
- "Simulation speed" accelerates or slows the integrator; values above 1.0 speed the dynamics up.
- "Left wall temperature" and "Right wall temperature" modify the boundary conditions instantly and recolor the walls to show the heat gradient.
- "Particle scale" enlarges or shrinks the rendered particles together with their collision radius.
- "Tagged particles" defines how many highlighted particles appear after you press "Add particles".
- "Particle size" and other physical coefficients (elasticity, nonlinearity, mass) influence how collisions behave.

sections.heading: Inside the demonstration
items: - "Add particles" injects the requested amount of tagged particles so their trajectories are easier to follow.
- "Apply" pushes every slider value (except the live wall temperatures) into the simulator and restarts the run.
- "Dim background/Restore colors" toggles a calmer palette for untagged particles, while "Show trail/Hide trail" draws a trajectory for the highlighted particle.
- "Reset" clears the heat-flux counters; the right-hand panel reports the current flux and accumulated energy.
- "Show graph borders" locks the axis range so you can compare different runs more easily.
- The "Main menu" button leaves the scene; restarting from the menu resets the simulation state.

sections.heading: Observations and measurements
items: - The right panel displays the current heat flux and accumulated energy; values update in real time.
- Wall hit counters (left/right) help you see how energy transfer balances between boundaries.
- Mean kinetic and potential energies are plotted so you can track the approach to steady state.

sections.heading: Controls and tips
items: - Use the mouse wheel on the "Tutorial" text to scroll longer instructions.
- After adjusting several sliders, press "Apply" once to commit all changes together.
- For large temperature differences, lowering particle count or size can keep the simulation smooth.
